May 26, 1853 – At sunrise we have halted 12 miles from Carson river having traveled 29 miles since three o’clock yesterday, 11 o’clock and 20 minutes. We are now on Carson River, and have made the Riffle and crossed the great desert and are all alive which is better than many others have done, for we found some forty graves at this edge of those who had died, beside a great many on the desert, poor fellows. They have died within 60 miles of where gold has been dug. There are log cable chains enough on this desert to reach from Columbus to Cleveland via the Railroad, and dead cattle, horses, and mules, old wagons and irons of every description to build a turn pike the same distance. I saw whole teams of three and four yoke of cattle yoked and [illegible word] chained together that had struggled on for two thousand miles and here had lain down to rest and appeared to have fallen asleep, and had not awoke till the sand had drifted on their legs in such large piles that they could not wake to raise and had lain there ever since and dried up. I swung my ox whip over them and hallowed to them but all to no effect and indeed I don’t think anything will ever induce them to make an effort to get up til Gabril shall stand one foot on the little lake at the sink of the Humbolt and one foot on the desert and blows his horn to rise out of their sandy beds. My friend Taylor found the grave of a cousin on the desert. Taylor and myself with two others left the train at 3 o’clock and traveled on foot. We traveled 15 miles and halted at sunset, built a little fire on the river bank and got ourselves some supper. After supper we extinguished our fire and traveled three miles farther for safety from the Indians, and then laid down to sleep with nothing but our blankets and the heavens over us and all slept soundly all night through we did not consider it safe on account of the Indians being troublesome in this part of the country, but we had not slept in thirty hours and had walked all that time. My Ohio friends would think these hard times. “Well Jordan am a hard road to Travel”.

May 27, 1853 – Awoke early this morning much rested, and unmolested by the Indians. We walked 30 miles today, 26 of which was a desert. We laid ourselves down as usual on the ground and slept soundly.

May 28, 1853 – After walking 5 miles this morning we reached the summit of a high hill and looked down on a hundred miners who were digging gold in Gold Canyon Carson Valley. We raised a shout and was answered by the miners below. We are the first who have reached this place this season across the plains. We are yet 150 miles from the mines in Cal. on the other side of the Sierra Nevada Mountains. It is now 14 months and 11 days since I left home and today for the first time I have seen gold dug from the earth. My friend Taylor and I are as well pleased as though we had just got home with our fortunes. We have bought ourselves a Long-Tom, expect soon to t— some thing or get t—-ed the darndest. We can’t cross the mountains for a week on account of the snow. We intend to go on as soon as we can.

May 29, 1853 – Resting a little today which we very much need, after so long and tedious a trip.

May 30, 1853 – Took ourselves a claim and commenced mining on our own hook. G. King.

May 31, 1853 – Mining again today, had very little success yesterday and a poor prospect today.

June 1, 1853 – Mining as usual.

June 2, 1853 – Working in our claim today.

June 3, 1853 – Made $4 to the hand, or man. Sold our Tom to some green horns (we call ourselves miners) and got $12 more than we gave for it and tomorrow we resume our journey for the other side of the mountains.

June 4, 1853 – Started this morning early traveled thirty miles and encamped for the night.

June 5, 1853 – Crossed the first summit of the Sierra Nevada mountains and encamped on the shore of Lake Bigler — a beautiful lake situated between the two summits of the mountains and is ten miles long and 3 miles wide.

June 6, 1853 – Crossed the second summit early this morning. Snow several feet deep and hard enough to bear a male. We are now in Cal. and descending the western slope towards the Pacific Ocean. Saw any amount of grisly bear tracks in the snow during the day. Traveled 20 miles and Taylor and I got lost and had to lay out and neither of us knew the other was lost till next morning.

June 7, 1853 – Started early this morning and traveled 25 miles and encamped within 4 miles of Hang Town — the first mining town on the emigrant road.

June 8, 1853 – Moved on into town, and had the good fortune to hire in a sawmill at $75 per month and commenced at noon the same day. Worked 5 days, and left thinking I could do better and went to mining. Made $10.50 the first day.

* The G.W. King journal ends here. Published in The Pastfinder, Newsletter of the Ashland County Chapter Ohio Historical Society

This letter was written by Mary Adeline (Richards) Welton (1814-1873), the wife of Hobart Victory Welton (1811-1895) of Waterbury, Connecticut. Mary wrote the letter from her parents farm in Westminster, Wyndham County, Vermont, where we learn she had traveled by stage with her seventeen month-old son, Edwin Davis Welton (born 4 April 1836). Mary’s parents were Luther Abijah Richards (1785-1840) and Mary Page (1796-1840).

While art was his passion, Hobart Victory Welton was a successful farmer and was “equally accomplished as an engineer. He served as superintendent of the city roads for 25 years, oversaw the construction of a system of reservoirs on the Mad River to power brass factories, engineered Waterbury’s first stone bridge with an arch in 1848, and engineered Connecticut’s first iron bridge in 1863, built over the Naugatuck River at West Main Street. Welton served in the State Legislature in 1852 and 1853. He died in 1895, but his art continues to influence us today.” [See Waterbury Thoughts]

TRANSCRIPTION

Addressed to Mr. Hobart V. Welton, Waterbury, Connecticut

Westminster [Vermont]

September 1837

Monday afternoon

Beloved Husband,

I thought when I left you I should send a before before I wrote, but thinking you will be anxious to know about my journey, as well as how I found my friends, I have concluded to alter my arrangement.

I found my journey not as fatiguing as I expected, for I thought it would make me down sick. I rode with those four gentlemen until we reached Springfield (one was, however, a drunkard and can hardly bear the appellation of gentleman). At Springfield, a lady took the stage and rode to Bernardston within ten miles of Brattleborough. The rest of the way was with gentlemen who were very kind and offered to assist me in carrying Edwin; one gentleman carried him perhaps two hours which was the only relief I had. He was sick the last day and would go to no one but me. I do not know whether it was stage sickness or being irregular about his food and eating a pear to quench his thirst. He has not yet got to be quite himself yet. Does not play about as much as when at home and likes to be nearer mother than usual and nearer than I like most of the time. But I think he will get over it when he gets better acquainted with the children. They all call him a father boy.

I have felt about half way sick even since I have been here a violent headache and sore throat accompanied with laziness has been my chief complaint. I found our family well except Father. He appears workout with hard work and is now so busy he can hardly find time I would almost say to breathe. He has a Rye beard in one of his eyes which has been in three weeks and is very troublesome. This is now the season for pigeon’s in which Father is much engaged.

He has nearly completed his barn and I wish I could give you a description of the buildings as they are now arranged more convenient than any I have before seen. First he has a large shed to grind scythes and the like with a room joining for carriages. Next is a shed to drive under to unharness connected with his horse barn which is divided into five tables for horses which occupies one half onf the barn. The other half is divided into a granary and harness room, and a wool room, a chamber above for hay, a hog pen joining. These are all on the opposite side of the yard from the house. I wish you could visit Westminster before you finish your barn.

I suppose you are this week at work at Mr. Platt, and I fear you will make yourself sick by working in the water. I look for Mrs. Platt every day.

Father says you could purchase sawed chestnut shingles for about two dollars and a quarter. Pine, he thinks, at between 3 and 4 dollars. He says he shall be going to Bellow’s Falls before many days and can ascertain for what they may be bought, and also what it cost to send them by water.

There were three or four passengers in the stage who were going north to buy cattle. I heard them remark that purchasers were very plenty. I judged by their conversation more so than they wished they told me for what they could buy cattle but I was sick with the headache with a sick child and paid but little regard to their conversation. But Father says have is very scarce and people will be obliged to sell.

Sarah and Russell are to be married sometime this fall. The day and hour is not yet set. I am quite anxious it should be that you may make your arrangements to be here at the time. R. has invited me to attend church at Bellow’s Falls with S. I hope you have no objections. If so, you will have time to send me word before we go. I have not seen Campbell yet. Aunt Richards has last week had a slight shock of Numb Palsy. Many think she will never recover to be as well as former. She is able to sit up and walk with assistance. It seems to have impaired her mind more than her body.

Tuesday morn. Last night we had rain which is the first they have had in a long time. I found it very dusty although not as bad riding in the night as in the day time.

Yours with true affection.

This letter was written by 19 year-old Jacob Howell (1827-1891), the son of Israel and Elizabeth (Rowland) Howell. Israel Howell was born in Philadelphia in 1786 where he was educated in the common schools and learned the tanner’s trade from his father. In 1828 he moved to Edgmont, Delaware County, Pennsylvania, where he purchased a farm of 200 acres and raised cattle. He founded the village of Howellville (now Gradyville). In 1848, after the sale of his property in Edgemont, he returned to Philadelphia where he worked in the custom house. He then moved his family to a farm of 60 acres in East Bradford. Besides Jacob, the other Howell children included Arthur, Mary Mott, Rowland (“Roll”), Israel, John Rowland, Sallie Rowland, Elizabeth or “Lizzy” (1834-1876), and Joshua Rowland.

Jacob (with a little help from Lizzy) wrote this letter to their older brother, Joshua Rowland Howell (1825-18xx). Joshua attended the Quaker boarding school at Westttown and then worked in a Monroe County tannery for six years. He then moved to Philadelphia were he worked in the leather business for fourteen years. In 1865, he left the business due to ill health and removed to East Bradford where he resided with his brother Jacob. He eventually purchased his own farm and raised cattle.

TRANSCRIPTION

Addressed to Joshua R. Howell, Fannersville P.O., Monroe County, Pennsylvania

First day [Sunday] afternoon, 26 of 7th Month [1846]

I expect thee, my dear brother, has or will be looking for a letter so I thought I would commence by saying Father arrived safely and thy letter was very acceptable. We have had company ever since Father’s return. The day before he came, Stanton Dorsey and Lizzy, also Lizzy Johnson and William Howell came out in the stage. William & Stanton started off on second day morn, washed on 2nd day, and just as we were done dinner the Westtown stage stopped and Mary Dickinson and child got out. She was an old acquaintance of Mothers.

Next day Father & Mother took her up to Westtown to see her daughter and just before they got home Elisabeth Pitfield (who was visiting meetings) Elisabeth Pierson, Charles Williams, & N. Sharpless drove up to stay all night so thee will see we have just been on the run the whole time.

Roley & Eben Levich came out yesterday week and last eve William H. came out. Roley seemed in pretty good spirits and I guess about wants another change. I do want to come up to see thee. E. L. says maybe Annie can come up with me and we will have a lovely time. Jacob is a going to write so I will say farewell. Thy affectionate sister. [– Lizzy]

[different hand writing]

Perhaps our Brother Joshua will think his friends at home have entirely forgotten him but can assure him that is not the case — far from it. But the cares on business of this vain world burden and crowd on us poor creatures and time passes so rapidly that a much longer time than was ever intended or thought of has passed since any have written to thee. Hope it will not happen so again. Well so much for a beginning. May says we are still staying here with no signs of escape — even if we wanted to go.

Suppose thee has heard of the sad catastrophe that has happened the Mill at Stafford. Roll was up last first day [and] seemed well satisfied with the prospect of getting out of the business — suppose he had been there long enough to get tired of it and a change will just suit him. Would thee like to have him up there for company?

We have got pretty much through with our harvesting and have had some pretty unfavorable weather for it. Suppose you have had your share of the same kind.

Is thee ever coming down to see us again for it seems a long time since I saw thee and think it would do me some good to see thy face and hear some good advice from thee and have some talk together — for I am almost out of conceit of everything in this world, may I say, for we seem only stay here now for we have no help — neither in the house not out of doors — except Grace — and what hiring we have to do and we do just what we have to and that is nearly all which keeps us busy. Now don’t thee think such getting along as that where there is so much to be done is only staying.

I long to see the time when we shall have all things finished hereabouts but am almost out of heart. We go on so slowly. I begin to think before we get finished out at one end the other will need repairing — and it is hardly likely I shall ever get away from home to learn how the world does as we talked of and recommended being so good for young people — must stay here all my days, I suppose, and come out a dunce at last. Well so much for myself. Suppose Lizzy has told all the news.

We are all pretty well now though last week Mother and myself were both under the weather. With love from us all. I remain affectionately thy brother, — Jacob

W. P. & S. C. Bangs have returned — came on 7th day. Expect they will be at meeting tomorrow, our Monthly meeting. They are all pretty well up there when we heard last. Poor Isaac Yarnall’s case is before the meeting. Will hear what is to be done with his poor soul. He comes to meeting regularly on 1st days now.

This letter was written by 21 year-old Harriet Richardson (1822-1854), the daughter of William Richardson (1787-1876) and Mary Pierson (1790-1875) of Stafford, Genesee County, New York. She wrote the letter to her older sister, Martha (Richardson) Conklin (1816-18xx), the wife of Elisha Conklin (1813-Aft1880) of Moravia, Cayuga County, New York. The Conklin’s later moved to Sempronius in Cayuga County.

In her letter, Harriet give all the local news and mentions the execution of Benjamin D. White (see footnotes) who was found guilty of murdering his father. The murder — a shooting– took place on 16 March 1842 at Batavia, New York. “A more deliberate, unnatural and wicked murder…can scarcely be found in the annals of crime,” wrote one correspondent covering the trial. It took the jurors less than 5 hours to return the verdict.

TRANSCRIPTION

Addressed to Mr. Elisha Conklin, Moravia, Cayuga County, New York

Stafford [Genesee County, New York]

April 27, 1843

Dear Brother and Sister,

What a long time since I have written one word to you — more than a year, would you think it? And yet, how short the time appears.

I have long thought of making you an epistolary visit, but have waited for something interesting to communicate. I am confident if I wait for that I shall never have the pleasure of writing. We have not heard from you in some weeks. How is your health now. Martha? We suppose you are well again else you would have written. What are you all about this Spring? And what do you think we are doing? I do not think you can guess so I will tell you. Father and the boys are building a stout board fence around the orchard and garden. James has ploughed and sowed peas. He says they are up. Mr. Havens transplanted a number of ____ trees. Got from Mrs. Burden’s garden a snow-ball, snowberry, cinnamon rose from Mr. Van Allen’s a very large sweet brier. We intend to have the garden west of the house for flowers together with vegetables. Miss Sally Gilbert gave me a number of house plants, four kinds of geranium, dew plant, german, and monthly rose (Mary’s plants all died but one). Do you not think we shall have enough to do to attend to all these things?

But you ask what are all you girls doing? We are at present engaged with your quilt. Put it on last week. Have quilted I will not say how much. I fear we should all blush if I told. I think we shall have work enough for this week and next. Mary is afraid it will not look as nice as hers. It quilts very hard — the lining is so thick. She got hers and told us just what blocks you quilted and said we must so yours as nice as those were. Mary says she shall take it to the fair in the fall and get prize enough to take her to Moravia. What do you think of that? I imagine she makes large calculations.

Mary and Kate will probably stay at home this summer. I expect to teach in the stone house east. Shall commence as soon as the walking is good. I suppose Martha you can imagine how I will look there. Just step in with Elisha and see me. I shall have some of the same scholars that you had. Have twelve shillings a week for six months if I please. The district generally and I like the school, walking good &c.

I must bid you good night as it is quite late. The family are all in bed and I ought to be there. I have lots of news to tell you tomorrow. Benjamin White ¹ was executed yesterday at four. About fifty were admitted into the yard to see him — some of our neighbors. Many paid a shilling for the privilege of standing on the top of a barn where they could see him. He spoke very lengthy. His last words were he wished the people to remember that he had never believed there was any God and died as he lived — a deist. Some thought he appeared agitated; others said he did not in the least, and appeared rather lively. Good night and sweet be your sleep. {eleven o’clock}

Friday Evening half past 6

Martha, I need not quilt anymore today, need I? You say no. Well then I will talk to you. I imagine you will ask a great many questions. We heard from Brother Ham about two weeks ago. He was at Flint and had been for some time settling up about his land. He said he owned more than a thousand acres and wished Pa to sell it. If he could, he was going to start the next week for Milwaukie. Said we would hear from him again soon after his arrival there.

Ira D. Wright was married when H. was here to Miss Margaret Ingersoll. R. F. Page spent most of the winter and spring at Stafford. My pen is very poor. Would you laugh a little if I told you old Mrs. Wright was married? You will do no more than other folks did if you do. She was married a week last Sunday to a Deacon Brainard. The old gentleman came to Stafford last winter and told a friend of his that he wanted a wife. The lady recommended old Mrs. Wright. He went to Deacon Hickox and asked him to go with him next time.
